ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Out of class projects, out of class readings, out of class collaboration with peers.
Zoom, camera on, not recorded.
We also had monthly one-one-one meetings to get feedback

A combination of live virtual lecture and virtual seminar/discussion format. Some days were multi-hour lectures, other days were virtual group review, and some days would be shorter individual desk-crit style virtual meetings.
Live virtual studio, including seminar-like discussions and critiques, as well as small-group live virtual meetings
Professor Faruqee mailed/had us pickup the materials for her class, which was super nice and helpful!
Alternating between full class and small group meetings weekly over zoom.
Combination of seminar and virtual lectures, as well as individual meetings.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a deeper insight into creativity, and this course furthered my interest in the arts. Anoka did a fantastic job at leading me along that path.
I learned a lot about color perception, and how to practically apply color knowledge to my own art practice. Color manipulation/flexibility was the main insight I gained from this course.
I learned so much about using color across different mediums

I learned a lot about color theory and the different color systems used in digital versus print mediums. Learned a lot about how colors interact with each other a la Josef Albers. Also learned how to use gauche and how to mix color pigments. Overall a lot more comfortable painting and deliberately using color in art.
This course helped me further develop my eye for color and how different colors can interact and influence each other.
An undergraduate level course studying the application of colors across multiple mediums.
Wonderful class to learn the basics of color theory, specifically looking at Joseph Albers. I also developed my collage and painting skills.
I learned about color interaction and got to apply color to my own practice.
My knowledge of color in many different medias expanded greatly, and this in turn improved my painting skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I loved this course, but I think it would have been beneficial to have it in person. That is my sole complaint.
I thought this course translated very well into on online format!
Anoka and her TA are awesome at providing individual feedback and attention even online. They supported us during all of our creative directions.
I think any weaknesses in the course were due to it being virtual. Engagement from other students was low during critiques, though the zoom chat feature was useful to promote some discussion.

Strengths: Thoughtful criticisms from instructors, flexible assignments. 
Weaknesses: Lack of studio time, no structure near the end.
This course was helpful to me as an artist. I've been wanting to learn about color for a long time and felt I benefited from it. I did not put max engagement because of the virtual format.

Strengths: professor's engagement, individual attention, theory

Weaknesses: clear deadlines and instructions

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought this course was taught very well given the circumstances, but for a discussion course like this, having it in person would have worked wonders.
I think that my class could have been more vocal? Conversation was stiff for the first half of the semester.
She made zoom so engaging!

Aside from full class lectures, our other meeting times were within the class time period but attendance was through reservations that each student would individually make. This made the class a lot more flexible and greatly reduced Zoom fatigue.

Success: Digital art transitioned well
Improve: physical mediums and practices to share digitally.

The course was set up where wed do lectures or preliminary individual meetings to look at our art progress on Mondays and critiques on Wednesdays. It was a nice set up that meant you got a lot of feedback and were timely about doing the homework.
I think it was very hard to do this kind of critique-based art course on zoom. This class adapted well to the virtual format with a mix of digital assignments.

I think the shipping of kits and the use of the kits in class was extremely helpful and let me be very engaged in the course. Professor Faruqee did an amazing job helping us learn how to use the tools and incorporating the material into class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to every single student at Yale. It is fun, creative, insightful, and has changed my perspective on how I view color in the "real world".

I would definitely recommend this class to anyone who doesn't want to take a work-intensive class (as in physical drawing/painting), but still wants to receive an introduction to visual thinking/color thinking and to do some light, fairly structured projects.
YES!! I love Anoka, the projects were soooo funnn and the grading was very fair

Yes. Anoka is incredibly talented and a great teacher. The assignments are really fun and appropriately difficult for learning color interaction. Anoka is also very flexible and understanding. The larger assignments are also quite flexible in terms of what you produce, so you can choose the subject matter and medium that most appeals to you.
Yes, would highly suggest this course (especially to intended painting/printmaking majors) intent on having a greater understanding of color relationships and the history of color as well.
If they love art and want to improve their work.
I would recommend the course to any student wanting to learn about color for use in their art.
Yes, to anyone who is willing to work hard on their projects and really open their minds about what color is and how it can be utilized.
